comments.commentBody:
In novel "1984" the government controlled every aspect of life for everybody, even those who believed they were outside the government's authority. The discussions over the Leaks have the same quality.

What little I've read of those leaks hasn't changed my mind about any of the issues which this nation faces but is unable to do anything about. Issues like Iraq and Iran, Pakistan and Saudi Arabia, China and North Korea. It still seems that our government needs enemies in order to hold sway over it's own people, over us.

While I would like to see some of the communications from Iraq before and during the war to occupy and rebuild Iraq, I already have a good idea of what these cables would say. I hope you - the New York Times - highlights these cables in a an article. I've listened to David Brooks for years and he is the best double-speaker I know! I don't pay any attention to him... Gail is much more fun to read, but she hasn't told me anything I didn't already know, just a more humorous way of looking at it.

The leaked cables are bad for the world because they destroy trust? What trust?

Our government has told us over the years, for example, that a) Asia was certain to fall to the Communists like a row of dominoes, b) American boats were attacked in the Gulf of Tonkin, c) Saddam Hussein had WMD, d) the Watergate burglary was just a "caper" and e) Brownie was doing a "heckuva job" in New Orleans.

How many have died because our government was lying to us?

Anything the government does should presumptively be open to the public. While there are some legitimate state secrets, the burden should be on the government to show a need for secrecy.

If 3 million people, including (allegedly) an Army private, had access to the leaked cables, how can they be secret? So far, it has been another gossip dump that's no different than what we hear about all U.S. leaders on cable news or in the comments sections on the web. In fact, the Wikileak revelations are much nicer than what we hear at home.

Assange has done us all a great service.

It comes a bit too late to save the thousands of US military killed--or maimed for life--and the tens or hundreds (will we ever know?) of thousands of Iraqi and Afghan citizens killed.

Almost all of this human suffering and destruction was needless, and counterproductive. Are those countries now democracies, is the life of their citizens better? And, do they thank us--or do they hate us more, are some of them (relatives of those we've killed, even "accidentally") more determined to harm us?

Let us hope that in future such information will be made public in time to prevent such terrible errors.

At the expense of National Security, compromising other allies and general World Peace, this incident helps to publicly reveal a couple of very important facts:

1)- The incredible level of insecurity regarding U.S. State Secrets and the alarming vulnerability as how this type of very sensitive or classified intelligence can get in the hands of almost anyone.

2)- The current State of World Affairs & Insecurity regarding some of the World's Top Leaders and with regard to the irresponsibility, personality disorders and excesses of some of these characters. The very same individuals (most of them duly elected) who determine the well-being and security of not just their countries and people, but in fact, the Planet.

3)- The fact that things have not changed at all since the end of the Cold War and that espionage, deceit and manipulation is still the name of the game for the U.S. and other Major World Powers.

Last thought:

Imagine the type of sensitive information and intelligence that other countries have on the U.S. and regarding vital issues or chapters in U.S. history. i.e.- 9-11, The Kennedy Assassination, Nuclear Secrets, War on Terror, Human Rights abuses, Cuba, Foreign Policy, etc.

Scary!

Our corruption, Harding and broom closet aside, is not of the titilating kind---no buxum nurses. But Haliburton, Cheney, and the deep intertwining of public and private business that accelerated under W. Bush is very similar to the way the leaks describe current Russia. Except for a  Louisiana or Illinois congressman or two,, our corruption  doesn't often involve suitcases of cash as the leaks describe transactions in the Kremlin. But wired billions leaking from our taxes is just as corrupt, if not as colorful. Let's not feel too superior here.

What surprised me about this exchange was how little it has to offer; that neither Brooks or Collins possess anything that approaches wit. They might have well as sat down and read from prepared scripts. I also suspect the controversy regarding the "cables" has less to to with the nature their contents than with Julian Assange's bad behavior.

I wouldn't call the man a hero, as some have, although I'm grateful to him for demonstrating what we all know to be true anyway, that the world is run by fools and brutes and opportunists and that includes our inept, naive and apparently impotent State Department. That it doesn't just come undone, see Yeats' The Second Coming," I just wish this information didn't come to us from a man who has to work out his Oedipal issues in public. Nevertheless, I look forward to seeing more members of the mainstream media expressing their shock, shock at Mr. Assange's audacity,while secretly envying the man who is doing what they ought to do, but don't.

Amazing!!  all the folks who find the leaks trivial.  surely they aren't referring to the billions for Georgia or the coup in Honduras. Their comments are spin on spin. The leaks are not the abridged version folks.  If you take the time to write, start with taking the time to read.

This Wikileak is a good one for globalization, where no one is left out of the political discourse of the rich, powerful and the totally insane and visionless. Indeed, the veritable age of free and unfettered information is right here with us! Thank goodness. Free at last!
Something isn't adding up.  If there is nothing in these leaks, why is there so much apparent effort to shut the site down?

Opt-in is better than opt-out, but this is just fluff. We know how good and trustful are companies policing themselves...

The privacy has to be build into the Internet. That means that at least all the third party data/traffic should always go through a proxy!!

Browsers should have enhanced and clear to set privacy rules.

And no OS should ever allow any program to access the Internet/network without user explicit permit (one time, session, or a standing one like for a browser, email programs, etc..)
Look at all the cockroaches running when the lights are turned on...

Re the concern that Bad Guys might gain access to nukes in Pakistan and kill US, keep in mind that India has a close eye on such potentialities.  Also note that Our Good Guys and friends have caused roughly a half million persons to die directly and as "collateral damage" for vague and vacuous objectives.

This perverse admiration for blatant voyeruism is really troubling. How no one really seems to have a problem with someone stealing documents from within the government and giving them to someone with questionable motives who then makes them public is beyond me. These actions should universally be condemned.  This is not about free speech or our right to know, this is outright theft and  complete disregard for privacy.

I recently found a hefty "foreign transaction fee" on my credit card for an online ticket I bought on Jet Airways, an India based airline, because even though I bought it on the US website of the airline, it was charged as though I had bought it overseas. Any way to avoid such surcharges?

It is no wonder Southwest carries more passengers than anyone else. Who doesn't like no-nonsense pricing, a generous rewards program and employees genuinely seem to enjoy their work?

Do people really go to these lengths to save $35 - $50 on domestic airfares?

The suggestions in this column are silly.

Delta claims to provide a "free bag" with the use of its American Express card. I assumed, having read or heard nothing to the contrary, that it applied to all flights, so I found out "the hard way" that it doesn't apply to international flights.

In a related incident of corporate presumption, I departed Heathrow on 17-Nov, checking one bag, and it was 8 kg overweight: I was charged GBP 129 (over $200). That charge doesn't bear any relationship to the cost to the airline of that additional weight. I haven't located a figure that high in any Delta "literature" regarding overweight baggage. Is it punitive? I was given no guidance or instruction: at least I could have been told that it would be cheaper to acquire another suitcase and split the weight between them, as a second bag would cost less than one overweight bag. Unconscionable gouging invites regulation, in my opinion. As airlines consolidate, the "issue" will likely worsen. Naturally, my detailed written enquiry to Delta was met with cheap "boilerplate" rejection.

tried Roku, sent it back packed with its RMA. Ain't trying anymore, but thanks for the reviews.
I'll get the cheapest netbook around with hdmi output and stream through that to the TV. Perhaps a tablet would show up that fits the identikit?

I finally got rid of cable and used the savings to run Ethernet and HDMI around the house. I have a long HDMI cable going to the Living Room TV from my pc which uses a $35 splitter found on Amazon to get the signal there and to the pc. I use a bluetooth mouse (range of 20+ feet) to operate my pc from the living room. Now, I watch Netflix and Hulu and files on my pc (e.g., saved using the Windows Media Center DVR) from my living room with ease.

I ran Ethernet to the living room as well, but end up not using it. But the Ethernet running upstairs via the attic to an upstairs TV comes in Handy to watch Netflix or connect to Windows Media with an X-Box used as a Windows Media Extender (actually the only reason we got an X-Box!). We use a bluray player that has Netflix access for the upstairs TV (I don't want to pay X-Box extra just to get Netflix).

Before running Ethernet and HDMI, I originally got a WD-Live+ for streaming, but while it is good for accessing Netflix and files connected to it by USB, it does not work with Windows Media Center files. It was also horrible using Wi-FI or powerline adapters for an internet connection. When connected to Ethernet, it plays other files hosted on you pc well, e.g., mp4, mpeg, .avi . . .

I also found Zumocast which works well to host video (and other files) to play remotely via a browser or on an I-phone or I-Pad. This app is presently free on I-tunes App store.

I won't bother with most of your legitimate points in your review, since those above me have already noted them.

But thanks for calling Orb out on not including the manual. Come on people! I'm all for saving trees, energy, etc.; but for most things like this I WANT the manual. I don't want to have to hold up an iPad or netbook to read the instructions. I want a paper booklet.

As for the Orb, let's face it. Computers are already basically cheap enough to buy one for exclusive use with a TV, and even if they're not quite there yet, it's just too easy to hook up a laptop, netbook, or Mac Mini or similar up to one's TV.

Re #86, John Jameson: "Try letting the largest holder of the nation's actual mortgages...fail."

Sorry, Mr. Jameson, but that's the fault of the bank(s) for writing all those mortgages, chopping up and bundling them until their individual risks and values were so inscrutable you'd need a team of forensic accountants to trace the paper trail.

The banks---and the ratings agencies, and Fannie and Freddie MAC, and a deregulation-crazy executive branch---all got their hands dirty because everyone wanted their share of the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.

Then the rainbow came crashing down. But not on the banks and agencies and Congressional leaders---just the aspiring homeowners who now rue the day their desperation to achieve the fabled "American Dream," e.g., home ownership, and poor financial planning skills caught up with them.

And as for populist anger "displacing "critical thinking" and "discerning analysis," talk about selective reading and attention!

For starters, pick up Joe Nocera and Bethany McLean's book "All the Devils Are Here"; or Andrew Ross Sorkin's "Too Big to Fail." Monday-morning quarterbacking, you say? Then how about Warren Buffet's shareholder letters for the past decade; or Nouriel Roubini warnings?

Many people have understood exactly the events which "created the downturn," despite inept and craven regulators, unrepentant and cahooting ratings agencies, and downright blindly greedy and dishonest bankers---did you not see the farcical testimony in front of Congress?!

Painfully trite, indeed.

Matterhorn, the Imperfectionists, Room were all great. The Ask was my favorite though. Non-Fiction- the Big Short, Life by Richards, Autobiography of Mark Twain. Personally Henrietta Lacks I thought Henrietta Lacks was garbage.

Why Maria Cino?

Because she is a powerhouse­, indefatiga­ble chief executive. She's extremely likable, with the requisite public speaking eloquence to make an impact on the public.

In light of current concerns, she has the executive/­managerial record of impressive major results, and which especially reflect fundraisin­g prowess and fiscal responsibi­lity; in her political roles, she has demonstrat­ed a deep respect for the power of the ground game and the requiremen­ts for its successful implementa­tion.

Do not take a chance. Go with the one with the best record of bringing the right results: Maria Cino!

***BOTTOM LINE***
If you are asking the nation to accept a Treaty that requires a lesser number of weapons be kept to provide for the nation’s defense, then it is vital that the remaining smaller number of weapons retained in the arsenal work reliably and without failure. If you need to test the reduced number of weapons retained in the arsenal to ensure ultimate reliability and safety, you should.
